With this complete solution, you can boost efficiency and improve customer satisfaction across all your production services.

The Website App acts as a virtual showroom and a powerful tool for generating new leads.

h3.span: Designing an Optimized Warehouse and Operations System üì¶

template.p: By configuring the warehouse and operations, we can build a system tailored to your specific needs. This involves customizing all settings related to storage locations, packaging, stock move types, shipping connectors, and barcode configuration to ensure maximum efficiency.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-info pb-0 pt-3

ul.li: Establish reordering rules for each product to maintain your ideal stock levels. For these rules to be effective, be sure to accurately configure the lead times (the time required to replenish your stock).

In this database's demo data, the Reordering Rules are set to a "Manual" trigger. This means Odoo will propose replenishment in your replenishment dashboard, but you must manually approve them before the orders are created. To skip this manual approval step and have Odoo automatically create orders, simply set the Reordering Rules to an "Auto" trigger.

Start by creating your stock locations: For more accurate tracking, set up different locations to represent your storage areas. The production location has already been created for you, so there's no need to make a new one.

div.p: To make your workflow even more efficient, explore these features:

ul.li: Manufacturing 2 steps: Your current "Manufacturing 1 step" workflow takes components directly from stock. By switching to a 2-step process, you'll add a picking operation between your warehouse and production area. This is ideal for transferring entire packages, like a full bobbin of thread, rather than just a small portion.

Manufacturing 3 steps: If you need a dedicated storage step for finished products, change your warehouse settings to a 3-step workflow. This adds a final transfer step, moving completed items from the production area to their final storage location.

li.p: Package Types: Track specific types of packages.
Connected Printers: Set up automated label printing.
Shipping Connectors: Integrate directly with shipping carriers.
Multi-Step Operations: Choose a 1, 2, or 3-step process for receiving and shipping goods in your Warehouse Settings.
Dropshipping route: Enable this for products that are shipped directly from a supplier's location to another destination without ever entering your warehouse.

div.p: The Odoo Inventory module is very powerful. While many great features are available, it's best to start with a simple process and add new features only after you've had time to test them.

p.span: To manage your production workflow, go to the Manufacturing application. From there, you can create your work centers, operations, and bills of materials..

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-info pb-0 pt-3

ul.li: Go to Settings to create and configure your work centers, which are the locations where your production operations happen. You can also adjust their specific parameters to fit your needs.

template.p: To create a new Bill of Materials from scratch, you'll need to know that there are two distinct types: Production BOMs (for in-house production) and Subcontracting BOMs (for external production). Each type requires different settings.

li.p: Navigate to the Bill of Material section and create a new BOM.
Select the finished product you are creating.
Add all the components needed for production and adjust their quantities.
Adjust the Manufacturing Lead Time (the time needed for production) and the Days to Prepare Manufacturing (the time needed to replenish or produce all components).
Create the operations, link them to their respective work centers, and specify the required time for each.

template.p: For products with different variations, such as a "T-shirt" that comes in "Blue" and "Yellow," a Bill of Materials (BOM) can be set up to handle all variants at once. This is done by linking specific components to certain variations.
Here's how it works:

li.p: T-shirt (Finished Product): Has two variants, "Blue" and "Yellow."
Component List:
Yellow Cotton: Only applies to the "Yellow" T-shirt variant.
Blue Cotton: Only applies to the "Blue" T-shirt variant.
Clothing Label: Applies to both variants (when setting is empty)

template.p: When you create a manufacturing order for a specific variant, such as a "Yellow" T-shirt, the system automatically pulls only the necessary materials‚Äîin this case, the Yellow Cotton and the Clothing Label. This approach helps streamline the production process and ensures you only use the components needed for each specific version of the product.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-warning pb-0 pt-3

div.p: Working with Bill of Materials (BOM) variants is a great way to automate the replenishment of specific components. However, this approach can add complexity and make it difficult to simplify your product structure later on.

It's usually better to start with a greater number of individual products and fewer variants. Once you're confident in your workflow and automation needs, you can then combine these products into a single product with multiple variants. This approach allows you to build a more robust and scalable system without the added complexity of variants from the start.

template.p: You can create multiple Bills of Materials (BOMs) for the same finished product. This is useful for products that can be made in different ways.
For example, a T-shirt with a custom-printed logo could have two different BOMs:

li.p: BOM 1: Full Fabrication This BOM would include all raw materials, like the fabric and thread, to make the T-shirt from scratch.
BOM 2: Reusing Stock This BOM would be used if you already have plain T-shirts in stock. It would only include the components needed to add the logo.

template.p: This flexibility allows you to manage different production processes for the same product, making it easy to use existing inventory when possible.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-success pb-0 pt-3

li.p: Create BOMs for a single unit: It's often easier to define your Bill of Materials for just one unit.
Use the batch size setting: If you always produce in batches of a specific quantity, use the Batch Size setting in the Miscellaneous tab.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-info pb-0 pt-3

li.p: By-products: Manage leftovers from production and track them as valuable inventory.
Work Center Capacity: Optimize your production schedule by exploring the capacity of your work centers.
Navigate to the Bill of Materials section and create a new one.
Choose the finished product you'll be receiving from your subcontractor.
Change the BOM type to Subcontractor.
Add only the components you need to provide to the subcontractor.

template.p: For example, if a subcontractor dyes your raw cotton, and they provide the ink and other materials, your BOM should only list the raw cotton. The components listed here are only those you will supply.
On the finished product's settings, you'll need to add the subcontractor to the vendor list. Be sure to include the price you'll pay for their subcontracting service.
Customers can request a quote directly from your website's contact form. You can then follow up with them in the CRM app to clarify their needs using the chatter feature.
Once their requirements are clear, you have two possible workflows:

li.p: For Make-to-Stock (MTS) or Make-to-Order (MTO) Products: Simply create a quote with the correct product. When the customer confirms it, Odoo will automatically create a delivery order. Whether a production order is also created depends on your settings, which are detailed in the Manufacturing Order Creation section.
For Engineer-to-Order (ETO): From the CRM, create a new project by clicking the ‚öôÔ∏è icon and selecting a template. This project will allow you to manage all the pre-sales steps, such as:
Design validation
Pattern creation
Pattern delivery

template.p: After these steps are complete, you can generate a new quotation directly from the project, reusing the information from the design and pattern. This ensures a smooth transition from the initial project phase to the final sales order.
For certain client orders, you need to get approval before starting production. The Project app centralizes all the necessary information, ensuring a smooth and perfectly managed follow-up process.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-info pb-0 pt-3

div.p: Create project templates within the Project app to easily reuse for similar projects.

template.p: Projects give you full control over the design process:

li.p: You can choose to charge a standard price for your design work or track the time spent and bill the client later.
You also have the flexibility to invoice for these services at any point, or even include them for free if the client agrees to the final quote.
When you're ready, create a Manufacturing Order specifically for the pattern and initiate production (don't link a Bill of Materials (BOM) for this one, as it doesn't have one)

ul.li: To include all the necessary information, such as the logo to be printed, technical measurements, and other details, you can choose one of two methods:

li.p: Direct Integration: Add all the details directly to the manufacturing operations.

Link to a Knowledge Page: Gather all the information in a separate knowledge page and then link that page to the manufacturing instructions. This keeps the operations clean while providing all the necessary details.
If a Sales Order exists for the pattern, the delivery will be created automatically. Otherwise, you must create the delivery for the client manually.
If any materials are required, use the Purchase app to manage your purchase orders.

template.p: Once the client approves the pattern, you can send the quote with the final product and price. This time, the delivery will be created directly from the Sales Order.
A key tip: Don't create a new product for each order. Instead, use a generic product and differentiate it using the lot number. You can then link the correct production order to the right delivery.

For larger production orders, such as those for a final product rather than a pattern for validation, it's crucial to follow clear plans for scheduling, instructions, subcontracting, and replenishment. The Manufacturing app is the best way to manage this process.
The delivery for these orders will be created automatically from the Sales Order.

span.strong: Production Created from a Pattern (ETO Process) & Production for Make-to-Order (MTO)

template.p: The process for creating a production order is similar for both Engineer-to-Order (ETO) and Make-to-Order (MTO) products. To allow for greater flexibility in choosing the correct Bill of Materials (BOM) and making any needed adjustments, you must manually create a manufacturing order after a sales order is confirmed.

li.p: From your project, select the production pattern.
Click the "Generate BOM" button. (This button is only visible if a BOM has not yet been selected on the manufacturing order.)
Create a new manufacturing order for the product, using the BOM you just generated.
Create a new manufacturing order.
Select the desired BOM.
Adjust the production quantity and any specific operations as needed.
If you have a knowledge page to centralize product customization, you can link it in the notes section of the Miscellaneous tab.
Click the "Allocation" button, then select the sales order or delivery you want to fulfill.
Before confirming the manufacturing order, change the scheduled date. This date will serve as the deadline for replenishing all components.
After confirming, Odoo will automatically trigger any necessary replenishment if reordering rules are set to Auto. Otherwise, it will be displayed on the Replenishment Dashboard.

template.p: A Manufacturing Order will be created in one of two ways:

li.p: Automatically if the available stock falls below the minimum level set in the Reordering Rule.
Manually if the product doesn't have a Reordering Rule and there is no stock available.

template.p: Once production orders are confirmed, they need to be planned. The scheduled date on the Manufacturing Order (MO) is just an initial estimate and doesn't consider your actual capacity.

To plan your orders, go to the manufacturing app, select them, and click "Plan." The system will then generate a detailed schedule that accounts for the capacity of your work centers. You can see a clear overview of your schedule on the planning by work centers screen.
While you can manually move an operation with a simple drag and drop, keep in mind this change is isolated to that specific work order and will not re-plan the others.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-success pb-0 pt-3

ul.li: Tips for Changing Production Priorities: If you need to change the priority on your production plan, you'll have to re-plan the entire schedule. First, select all the Manufacturing Orders and "Unplan" them. Next, set the new priority (‚≠ê) for the orders you need to adjust, then "Re-plan" everything. This will ensure your new priorities are reflected in the schedule.
You can assign one or more employees to each operation. This makes them visible on the planning schedule and links the operations to the correct workers in the shop floor app.

template.p: Once production is planned, workers can execute and monitor their tasks using the Shop Floor App. This app can be installed as a standalone application. It's designed to be used by multiple employees on a single device, with each employee registering their work individually.
To get started:

li.p: Open the app, select the work centers and log in as an employee.
If a Manufacturing Order is planned and all necessary components are available, it will appear on your screen.
Select the work order to begin, follow the instructions, and mark it as done when complete.

div.p: Pro-Tip: You can print and use barcode commands with a scanner to automate and streamline your workflow.

template.p: The Inventory app allows you to manage all of your stock operations, including inputs, outputs, and internal movements. When you validate a purchase or sales order, a corresponding receipt or delivery is automatically created.

Purchase orders can be created automatically using reordering rules. However, if you don't use reordering rules or want to manually review future needs, you can use the Replenishment view in the Inventory app.

The Replenishment view gives you a clear overview of all current and future needs (you can adjust the Horizon settings to see what's coming up). From this screen, you can directly create purchase orders, subcontracting orders, or manufacturing orders.
Once you've created a purchase order, validate it in the Purchase app. This powerful app allows you to group orders, compare different supplier offers, track receipt accuracy, and more.

p.span: When a purchase order for a subcontracted product is created, the system handles the entire process. As long as your Bill of Materials (BOM) is accurate, the purchase order will automatically trigger a receipt for the final product and a replenishment order for all necessary components.

template.p: When you're ready to manage a transfer:

li.p: Open the transfer.
Adjust the quantity and add lot numbers as needed.
Change the destination location if necessary.
If needed, you can pack the products together to generate a single label for the entire package.

template.p: Note: If you validate a transfer for a partial quantity, the system will automatically create a backorder for the rest of the items.
Use barcode scanners to validate stock movements, identify pallet positions, and perform fast, accurate stock operations. Greatly improves warehouse efficiency and reduces human error.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-info pb-0 pt-3

ul.li: You can customize the settings for each operation type within the barcode application to control what is permitted during the process. This allows you to define specific rules for operations like picking, ensuring the barcode functionality aligns with your business workflow.

div.class: o_editor_banner user-select-none o-contenteditable-false lh-1 d-flex align-items-center alert alert-success pb-0 pt-3

ul.li: The barcode app can be installed as a standalone application on devices. This means people can use it without having access to the rest of the database.
You can print barcode commands to streamline your operations with quick scanning actions.

template.p: You can easily invoice clients directly from a Sales Order. Each order allows you to set specific payment terms and conditions tailored to that client or project.

When you're ready, you have the flexibility to create an invoice for either a full or a partial payment, such as a down payment. All invoices generated are tracked and can be managed through the Invoices app.
Odoo will help you adapt your website to fit your clients' needs perfectly. Easily integrate your internal policies, customize the contact form, showcase your latest products, and much more!
